articles.headline: Contending With the Pandemic, Wealthy Nations Wage Global Battle for Migrants
articles.snippet: Covid kept many people in place. Now several developed countries, facing aging labor forces and worker shortages, are racing to recruit, train and integrate foreigners.
articles.abstract: Covid kept many people in place. Now several developed countries, facing aging labor forces and worker shortages, are racing to recruit, train and integrate foreigners.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the global economy heats up and tries to put the pandemic aside, a battle for the young and able has begun. With fast-track visas and promises of permanent residency, many of the wealthy nations driving the recovery are sending a message to skilled immigrants all over the world: Help wanted. Now.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Christopher F. Schuetze

articles.headline: As Inflation Surges, Pakistan Seeks a $6 Billion I.M.F. Lifeline
articles.snippet: Rising prices and a weakened currency are straining households, intensifying pressure on Prime Minister Imran Khan to find solutions.
articles.abstract: Rising prices and a weakened currency are straining households, intensifying pressure on Prime Minister Imran Khan to find solutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Muhammad Nazir canceled his daughter’s wedding. He parks his motorcycle at home and walks to his shop. Many of his shelves are empty because he can’t afford to stock the same supply of candy, soft drinks and cookies that he once did.
articles.byline: By Emily Schmall and Salman Masood

articles.headline: Jury Finds Rally Organizers Responsible for Charlottesville Violence
articles.snippet: Jurors found the main organizers of the deadly far-right rally in Charlottesville, Va., in 2017 liable under state law, awarding more than $25 million in damages, but deadlocked on federal conspiracy charges.
articles.abstract: Jurors found the main organizers of the deadly far-right rally in Charlottesville, Va., in 2017 liable under state law, awarding more than $25 million in damages, but deadlocked on federal conspiracy charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Jurors on Tuesday found the main organizers of the deadly far-right rally in Charlottesville, Va., in 2017 liable under state law for injuries to counterprotesters, awarding more than $25 million in damages. But the jury deadlocked on two federal conspiracy charges.

articles.headline: Elizabeth Holmes Points Fingers at Others and Says She Was a Believer
articles.snippet: In her most substantial day of testimony, Ms. Holmes, the founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, painted herself as someone whose best intentions were misinterpreted.
articles.abstract: In her most substantial day of testimony, Ms. Holmes, the founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, painted herself as someone whose best intentions were misinterpreted.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Using charisma, poise and a smattering of scientific jargon, Elizabeth Holmes persuaded investors to give her nearly $1 billion to build Theranos, her blood testing start-up. That all came crashing down in 2018, after the company’s technology and business dealings were revealed to have major problems.

articles.headline: Wall Street Grudgingly Allows Remote Work as Bankers Dig In
articles.snippet: Finance employees who couldn’t imagine working from home before the pandemic are now reluctant to return to the office. Their bosses can’t figure out how to bring them back.
articles.abstract: Finance employees who couldn’t imagine working from home before the pandemic are now reluctant to return to the office. Their bosses can’t figure out how to bring them back.
articles.lead_paragraph: In her two decades on Wall Street, Nadia Batchelor never once thought she could do her job from home. Face-to-face meetings were a must for Ms. Batchelor, a senior executive at Jefferies, a New York investment bank. Without being in the same room as her clients and colleagues, she assumed, there was no way she could win their trust and do her job of introducing companies to potential investors.

articles.headline: The Inflation Miscalculation Complicating Biden’s Agenda
articles.snippet: Administration officials blame the Delta variant for a prolonged stretch of consumer spending on goods, rather than services, pushing up prices and creating a conundrum for the Fed.
articles.abstract: Administration officials blame the Delta variant for a prolonged stretch of consumer spending on goods, rather than services, pushing up prices and creating a conundrum for the Fed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s top economists have worried from the beginning of his administration that rising inflation could hamstring the economy’s recovery from recession, along with his presidency. Last spring, Mr. Biden’s advisers made a forecasting error that helped turn their fears into reality.

articles.headline: He’s Steering Volkswagen, With His Eyes on Beating Tesla
articles.snippet: Herbert Diess, the chief executive, seeks to cast VW as a dynamic, modern company, but his style risks the ire of its powerful works council.
articles.abstract: Herbert Diess, the chief executive, seeks to cast VW as a dynamic, modern company, but his style risks the ire of its powerful works council.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOLFSBURG, Germany — In July, when Herbert Diess, Volkswagen’s chief executive, wanted to congratulate the company for a strong first half of the year, he posted a video of himself zipping across a waterway at the company’s headquarters in Wolfsburg on an electric hydrofoil, delivering a message of thanks to VW’s roughly 200,000 workers.

articles.headline: A Tech Whistle-Blower Helps Others Speak Out
articles.snippet: Ifeoma Ozoma, who accused Pinterest of discrimination, has become a key figure in helping tech employees disclose, and fight, mistreatment at work.
articles.abstract: Ifeoma Ozoma, who accused Pinterest of discrimination, has become a key figure in helping tech employees disclose, and fight, mistreatment at work.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California signed a bill to expand protections for people who speak up about discrimination in the workplace.

articles.headline: The Best Tech Gifts That Aren’t Gadgets
articles.snippet: Supply-chain disruptions may make it tough to buy devices, but the most thoughtful presents were never tangible to begin with.
articles.abstract: Supply-chain disruptions may make it tough to buy devices, but the most thoughtful presents were never tangible to begin with.
articles.lead_paragraph: My favorite holiday tech gift doesn’t require batteries or software updates. It’s not even a gadget, though it was made with technology.

articles.headline: He Convinced Voters He Would Be Like Merkel. But Who Is Olaf Scholz?
articles.snippet: Germany’s next chancellor is something of an enigma. He comes to power with a dizzying array of challenges, raising questions about whether he can fill the very big shoes of his predecessor.
articles.abstract: Germany’s next chancellor is something of an enigma. He comes to power with a dizzying array of challenges, raising questions about whether he can fill the very big shoes of his predecessor.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Olaf Scholz succeeded in his campaign to become the next chancellor of Germany primarily by convincing voters that he would be very much like the towering and long-serving figure he will replace: Angela Merkel.
